metadata.title: Core Teachings
metadata.description: Deeper contemplations organized by theme, based on the Direct Path

teachings.title: The Simple Fact of Being Aware
teachings.content:
Before examining any particular experience, notice the simple fact that you are aware. This awareness is not something you do or acquire. It is what you are. It is present now, and has been present throughout your entire life.

Awareness is the constant factor in all experience. Every thought, feeling, sensation, and perception appears in and is known by awareness. While the content of experience is always changing, awareness itself remains unchanged. It is the still, silent presence behind and within all experience.

You cannot step outside of awareness to examine it as an object. Awareness is the knowing itself, not something that is known. It is closer to you than any thought, because it is what you are prior to all thinking.

teachings.title: Awareness Has No Qualities
teachings.content:
Awareness itself has no color, shape, size, or location. It has no beginning or end in time. Yet it is not nothing—it is the luminous presence that makes all experience possible.

When you look for awareness as an object, you will not find it. This is not because awareness doesn't exist, but because it is not an object. It is the subject—the knowing presence that is looking. Just as the eye cannot see itself directly, awareness cannot be objectified.

Yet awareness is self-knowing. It knows itself through being itself. You don't need to think about awareness to be aware. The simple recognition 'I am aware' is awareness knowing itself directly.

teachings.title: The Space of Awareness
teachings.content:
Imagine awareness as an infinite, transparent space in which all experience appears. Thoughts arise and subside like clouds in the sky. Feelings come and go like weather. Sensations and perceptions appear and disappear like images on a screen.

Just as the sky is not disturbed by clouds, and a screen is not altered by the images displayed on it, awareness is never disturbed or changed by experience. All experience borrows its existence from awareness, yet awareness remains pristine, untouched, ever-present.

You are this aware space. Not a space in awareness, but awareness itself—infinite, eternal, and indivisible.

teachings.title: Awareness Is Always Present
teachings.content:
Can you remember a time when you were not aware? Even in deep sleep, though there is no memory of experience, awareness is present as the darkness and peace of deep sleep. Upon waking, you know you slept well. Something must have been present to know this.

In waking and dreaming, awareness is obviously present. In deep sleep, awareness is present as the knowing of absence. Awareness never comes and goes. Only the content of experience comes and goes.

This eternal presence of awareness is what you are. You have never been absent. You have never not been. The sense of 'I am' that you have had since childhood is the continuous thread of awareness that runs through your entire life.

teachings.title: One Awareness
teachings.content:
When two people look at the same object, it appears that there are two separate awarenesses looking. But is awareness itself ever an object that can be divided or separated?

Awareness has no boundaries. Where would the boundary of awareness be? Can you find an edge to your awareness? When you look for the limits of awareness, you find only more awareness.

There is only one awareness, appearing as many perspectives. The awareness that reads these words is the same awareness that wrote them. We share our being with all things. This recognition is the foundation of love and compassion.

categories.title: The Nature of Experience
categories.description: Understanding thoughts, feelings, sensations, and perceptions

teachings.title: You Are Not Your Thoughts
teachings.content:
Thoughts appear in awareness like birds flying through the sky. They come and go, arise and subside, yet awareness remains unchanged. If you were your thoughts, you would disappear when thinking stops. But notice what happens when thinking briefly ceases—you are still here, still aware.

Thoughts are objects of experience, known by awareness. You, as awareness, are the subject that knows all thoughts. This doesn't mean thoughts are bad or should be eliminated. It simply means they are not what you are.

When you recognize yourself as awareness rather than as thoughts, thoughts lose their power to define or limit you. They become simply another appearance in the open space of awareness.

teachings.title: Feelings Are Visitors
teachings.content:
Every feeling, pleasant or unpleasant, is a temporary visitor in awareness. Feelings arise, stay for a time, and dissolve back into awareness. Yet awareness itself is never happy or sad, never anxious or peaceful. These are qualities of experience, not of awareness itself.

When you identify as a separate self, feelings seem to happen to 'me.' This creates resistance to uncomfortable feelings and clinging to pleasant ones. But when you recognize yourself as awareness, you see that feelings simply come and go. They are allowed to be as they are.

Awareness welcomes all feelings with equal intimacy. Nothing is rejected, nothing is pushed away. This complete allowing is the deepest form of acceptance, and it is the nature of awareness itself.

teachings.title: Sensations and the Body
teachings.content:
The body is known through sensations appearing in awareness. Close your eyes and notice the sensations that indicate the presence of the body—tingling, warmth, pressure, movement. These sensations appear in awareness just as sounds and sights do.

You are not the body. You are what is aware of the body. The body is an appearance in awareness, made of sensations, just as your night-dream body is made of dream sensations. When the body is not being perceived, as in deep sleep, you do not disappear. Awareness remains.

This doesn't mean the body is unreal or unimportant. It means the body is not the limits of what you are. Awareness is not located in or limited to the body. The body appears in awareness, not awareness in the body.

teachings.title: Perceptions Appear in Awareness
teachings.content:
It seems as if you, as a body-mind, are located in the world perceiving external objects. But upon investigation, this is not your actual experience. All perceptions—sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches—appear in awareness. You have never experienced anything outside of awareness.

The world as you know it is not 'out there' and awareness 'in here.' Both the world and the sense of being a separate person inside the world are appearances in awareness. Awareness is not in the world. The world is in awareness.

This understanding liberates perception from the burden of being separate from what is perceived. Subject and object are recognized as one—both made of the same knowing awareness.

teachings.title: The Separate Self Is a Thought-Feeling
teachings.content:
The sense of being a separate self is not an entity. It is an activity—a contraction of thinking and feeling that creates the appearance of being a limited person separate from awareness and the world.

Investigate this separate self. Where is it located? What is its color, shape, or size? Can you find it? Upon investigation, the separate self cannot be found. It is like a character in a dream—it seems real while the dream is believed, but it is made only of the substance of the dream.

You are not the separate self. You are the awareness in which the sense of separation appears and disappears. This recognition dissolves the root of suffering.

categories.title: The Nature of Peace and Happiness
categories.description: Recognizing peace and happiness as your nature

teachings.title: Peace Is Uncaused
teachings.content:
The peace you long for does not come from arranging circumstances in a particular way. If peace depended on circumstances, it would be temporary, disappearing when circumstances change. Yet the peace you truly seek is permanent, unchanging, causeless.

This peace is not a state of experience. It is the background of all experience. It is the nature of awareness itself. When you recognize yourself as awareness rather than as a separate self struggling with experience, this peace is revealed.

Peace is what you are, not what you get. It is always present, like the silence that underlies all sounds. It is not found by changing experience, but by recognizing what is aware of experience.

teachings.title: The Peace of Deep Sleep
teachings.content:
Everyone loves deep sleep. Why? Because in deep sleep, the activity of the separate self ceases. Seeking stops. Resistance dissolves. What remains is pure being, pure awareness, inherently peaceful.

The peace you experience in deep sleep is not caused by the absence of experience. It is the nature of your being, revealed when the agitation of seeking subsides. This same peace is present right now, in the midst of waking experience. It is the background that has been overlooked.

You don't need to wait for deep sleep to experience this peace. Simply notice what you are—awareness itself—and the peace that is your nature is recognized here and now.

teachings.title: Happiness Is Not in Objects
teachings.content:
The belief that happiness comes from acquiring objects or experiences drives all seeking. Yet if you investigate carefully, you'll notice that happiness never actually comes from the object. It comes from the temporary cessation of seeking that occurs when a desire is fulfilled.

In that moment of fulfillment, the separate self relaxes. Seeking stops. And in that brief opening, the happiness that is the nature of your being is revealed. The mistake is to attribute this happiness to the object, rather than recognizing it as your own nature.

You are the happiness you seek. It is not found in experience. It is found as what you are—awareness itself, inherently whole, complete, and fulfilled.

teachings.title: The End of Seeking
teachings.content:
All seeking is based on the belief that you lack something, that you are incomplete as you are. This belief is the root activity of the separate self. As long as you believe you are incomplete, seeking will continue.

But what if you are already complete? What if nothing is lacking? What if the happiness and peace you seek are already present as the nature of your being? This is not a belief to adopt, but a recognition to be confirmed through investigation.

When seeking ceases, not through suppression but through recognition, what remains is the natural happiness and peace of being. This is not the end of activity or desire. It is the end of the compulsive seeking that drives the separate self.

teachings.title: The Direct Path Versus the Progressive Path
teachings.content:
The progressive path assumes you are not yet awareness, and that through practice and purification, you will eventually become or realize awareness. It promises future freedom through gradual development.

The direct path recognizes that you are already awareness. Nothing needs to be acquired, developed, or purified. The only 'problem' is that this simple fact has been overlooked. The direct path is the immediate recognition of what you already are.

Both paths can be valid at different stages. The progressive path can prepare the mind for recognition. But ultimately, recognition is immediate. There is no distance to travel, no time required. You are already what you seek.

teachings.title: No Distance to Travel
teachings.content:
The separate self is structured by the belief that awareness is somewhere else, something other than what you are now. This creates the search for enlightenment, awakening, or realization. The search implies distance—something to travel toward, something to acquire.

But how can you travel to what you already are? How can you acquire what you have never lost? The pathless path recognizes that there is no distance to travel. You are already home. You have always been home.

This recognition may seem too simple, too close, too obvious. The mind overlooks it, seeking something more exotic, more distant, more special. But the truth is always simple, always present, always here.

teachings.title: Practices as Preparation or Celebration
teachings.content:
If you are already awareness, what is the role of spiritual practices? Practices can serve two purposes: they can prepare the mind for recognition, or they can be a celebration of recognition.

As preparation, practices help quiet the agitated mind, clarify perception, and direct attention toward awareness rather than objects. They create the conditions in which recognition is more likely to occur.

As celebration, practices become an expression of recognition rather than a means to achieve it. Meditation becomes the recognition of awareness. Contemplation becomes the clarification of understanding. Devotion becomes the love of being. The practice and the goal are recognized as one.

categories.title: Being and Love
categories.description: Recognizing shared being and the nature of love

teachings.title: Shared Being
teachings.content:
The belief in separation creates the sense that you are here and others are there, that your being is separate from the being of others. But is this true? Is your awareness separate from the awareness of another?

Awareness has no boundaries, no inside or outside. The awareness reading these words now is the same awareness that wrote them. There are not many awarenesses, each limited to a separate body-mind. There is only one awareness, appearing from different perspectives.

This recognition that we share our being is the foundation of love. Love is not a feeling that comes and goes. It is the natural condition when separation is seen through. It is the recognition that what you are is not separate from what everything is.

teachings.title: The Nature of Love
teachings.content:
Love is often thought to be a feeling, a particular emotional state. But the love that is your nature is not a feeling. It is the recognition of shared being, the dissolution of the sense of separation between self and other.

When the separate self relaxes, there is no one here and something else there. There is only being, aware of itself in infinite forms. This is love—not as a feeling, but as the recognition of intimacy, of oneness, of non-separation.

This love doesn't exclude anyone or anything. It is not selective. It is the natural condition of awareness that recognizes itself in all experience, in all beings. It is what you are when the activity of separation ceases.

teachings.title: Compassion and Understanding
teachings.content:
When you recognize that you share your being with all beings, compassion arises naturally. The suffering of another is no longer 'their' suffering. It is suffering appearing in the one awareness that you are.

Compassion is not pity or sympathy from a distance. It is the recognition that there is no distance. What appears as 'other' is made of the same awareness, the same being, that you are.

This understanding doesn't mean you can or should eliminate all suffering. It means you respond to suffering from the recognition of shared being, rather than from the separate self that feels superior or separate from those who suffer. Action that flows from this understanding is inherently loving and wise.

teachings.title: Who Am I?
teachings.content:
The question 'Who am I?' is not an intellectual question seeking a verbal answer. It is a laser that dissolves the separate self by directing attention back to its source.

When you ask 'Who am I?', don't answer with thoughts. Instead, turn attention away from all objects of experience—thoughts, feelings, sensations, perceptions—and toward the subject that is aware. Who or what is aware of this experience?

As you rest in this inquiry, the separate self has no ground to stand on. It cannot be found. What remains is simple, obvious, ever-present awareness. This is what you are.

teachings.title: What Is Aware?
teachings.content:
Throughout the day, pause and ask: What is aware of this experience? What is aware of this thought? What is aware of this feeling? What is aware of this sensation?

This question directs attention from the content of experience to the awareness of experience. It is a gentle return to your true nature, repeated again and again until recognition stabilizes.

The answer is not found in thought. The answer is the simple recognition of presence, of being, of awareness itself. You don't need to name it or describe it. Simply notice it, recognize it, rest as it.

teachings.title: Am I Aware?
teachings.content:
The simplest inquiry is also the most direct: Am I aware? The answer is immediately obvious. Yes. This simple recognition returns you to your true nature in an instant.

You don't need to think about whether you're aware. You don't need to analyze or understand. The recognition is immediate and direct. You are aware. You cannot not be aware.

This question can be asked at any moment, in any circumstance. It is always available, always immediate, always pointing to what you are. Am I aware? Yes. Rest there.

teachings.title: Investigating the Separate Self
teachings.content:
The separate self is the root belief that obscures your true nature. To investigate it is to see through it. Begin by asking: Where is this 'I' that seems to be a separate person? Can it be found?

Look for the thinker of thoughts. Look for the doer of actions. Look for the experiencer of experience. What you will find is that these cannot be located as entities. They are activities that appear in awareness, not what you are.

The separate self is not your enemy to be destroyed. It is a misunderstanding to be seen through. When it is investigated, it is found to be empty. What remains is awareness itself, free of the burden of being a limited, separate person.

categories.title: Living the Understanding
categories.description: Allowing recognition to permeate daily life

teachings.title: From Recognition to Expression
teachings.content:
Recognition is instantaneous, but allowing this understanding to permeate the body-mind takes time. Old habits of thinking and feeling, based on the separate self, may continue for a while even after recognition occurs.

This is natural. Don't resist these habits. Simply continue to return to your true nature. As recognition deepens and stabilizes, the body-mind gradually aligns with the understanding. Thoughts, feelings, and behaviors naturally begin to flow from awareness rather than from the separate self.

This is not something you do. It is something that happens naturally as recognition clarifies. Trust the process. Be patient with the body-mind. Keep returning to awareness.

teachings.title: Awareness in Activity
teachings.content:
The recognition of awareness is not limited to sitting quietly. Awareness is equally present in activity as in stillness, in sound as in silence, in complexity as in simplicity.

The question is not whether to act or not act, but from where action flows. Does action flow from the separate self, driven by lack and seeking? Or does it flow from awareness, from the recognition of wholeness and completeness?

When action flows from awareness, it is effortless, creative, and loving. There is no one doing, only doing happening. This is the natural expression of awareness in the world.

teachings.title: Welcoming All Experience
teachings.content:
The recognition of awareness doesn't mean difficult experiences disappear. Challenges, pain, and loss may still occur. The difference is in how they are met.

When you know yourself as awareness, experience is no longer divided into 'good' that should be kept and 'bad' that should be rejected. All experience is welcomed in awareness with equal intimacy. Nothing is resisted. Nothing is pushed away.

This welcoming is not passive acceptance of harmful behavior. It is the recognition that resistance to experience creates suffering. When resistance dissolves, what remains is the natural intelligence and love of awareness responding appropriately to each situation.
